Sometimes, they will have lots of dramatized violence, known as action movies. Sometimes they will intend to make you laugh, these are called comedy movies. There are even some movies which are made up solely of cartoons simulated to move, known as “animated” movies (think of it like a hentai that doesn’t include pornography.)
A tv show is a sort of a series of shorter movies, known as episodes. Episodes can be as short as ten minutes or as long as an hour. Tv shows are generally broadcast on a weekly basis, with a break during the year. The time they are broadcasting is called a “season.” Basically, imagine if you were watching one of your porn movies, and it was twenty minutes long, and played on Wednesday at 8 O’clock. and then next week, the same actors came back and did a different porn, that built on the porn they did last week, that was twenty minutes long and played on Wednesday at 8 O’clock. posts.com:
I'm interested in fiction books that are based on something in the public domain. For example, I really enjoy the animated Disney series "TaleSpin" which is a spinoff of the PD "The Jungle Book," by Rudyard Kipling. TaleSpin has a much different setting and plot than TJB but uses a lot of the same characters and introduces new ones. I'm also interested in retellings, reimaginings, sequels, spinoffs, prequels, ect, of PD stories, myths, ect. Short stories, poetry, ect, are all also welcome.

Other examples could be putting Dracula in a romcom, or putting Dr. Frankenstein in a slice of life novel. I want to see how different authors put their own spin on the same story/characters. I hope you get the gist of what I'm looking for. So, any suggestions? Movies, games, comics, ect, are all acceptable, as well, but I'm primarily interested in books.

All genres and ratings are fine, by the way. Old, new, doesn't matter. Foreign stuff that's been English-translated are okay. Thanks in advance for any help. Have a great day, guys.

>>1310507
Ivanhoe comes to mind for Robin Hood, as does The Once and Future King for King Arthur. If you have any inkling for Rome, I, Claudius is pretty interesting, as the broad strokes of the story actually happened, but the author took some liberties in characterization and motivations to link things together

Outside of literature, Dragonball starts as a re-imagining of Journey to the West, and O Brother, Where Art Thou is based on The Odyssey. The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen comic might interest you as well, but I don't know anything else about it.

You’d be interested in the Wold Newton Family
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wold_Newton_family
>The Wold Newton family is a literary concept derived from a form of crossover fiction developed by the American science fiction writer Philip José Farmer.
>In real life a meteorite, called the Wold Cottage meteorite, fell near Wold Newton, Yorkshire, England, on December 13, 1795.
>Farmer suggested in two fictional biographies, Tarzan Alive: A Definitive Biography of Lord Greystoke (1972) and Doc Savage: His Apocalyptic Life (1973) that this meteorite caused genetic mutations in the occupants of two passing coaches due to ionization. Many of their descendants were thus endowed with extremely high intelligence and strength, as well as an exceptional capacity and drive to perform good or, as the case may be, evil deeds. The progeny of these travellers are purported to have been the real-life originals of fictionalised characters, both heroic and villainous, over the last few hundred years.
>As well as Tarzan and Doc Savage, both Lord Peter Wimsey and Sherlock Holmes are descendants of the original families. Other popular characters included by Farmer as members of the Wold Newton family are Solomon Kane; Captain Blood; The Scarlet Pimpernel; Sherlock Holmes's nemesis Professor Moriarty; Phileas Fogg; The Time Traveller (main character of The Time Machine by H. G. Wells); Allan Quatermain; A. J. Raffles; Professor Challenger; Richard Hannay; Bulldog Drummond; the evil Fu Manchu and his adversary, Sir Denis Nayland Smith; G-8; The Shadow; Sam Spade; Doc Savage's cousin Patricia Savage and one of his five assistants, Monk Mayfair; The Spider; Nero Wolfe; Mr. Moto; The Avenger; Philip Marlowe; James Bond; Lew Archer; Travis McGee; Monsieur Lecoq; and Arsène Lupin.

posts.com:
>>1311027
>I intend to use it for databases mainly.
Then you'll need fast storage, which means one with at least PCIe 4.0, which a lot of the G processors don't have. Annoyingly, with AM4, you'll often need a GPU just to get video output and full-speed NVMe from the same computer.

From your list, processors that won't be good for database work include: 4500, 4600G, 5500, 5600G, 5700G. You didn't mention 5600, but it does have 4.0, unlike 5500.

From your list, you really want a 7xxx, because they have onboard graphics across the board, and PCIe 5.0 so long as it's not disabled because your motherboard isn't expensive enough.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
if your video source is from youtube, you can use https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp to download the video
and then use https://avidemux.sourceforge.net/ to losslessly cut out the section of the video you want to post

"yt-dlp -F" will list the formats of a youtube video
https://gist.github.com/sidneys/7095afe4da4ae58694d128b1034e01e2
find
because most boards disallow audio, you will only want to download the video
for example:
yt-dlp -f 244 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-e1_QhJ1EhQ
you need to make sure the format is vp9, mp4 isn't supported

then open up avidemux to cut the video
video output by default is "copy", so you don't need to encode at all
change the output format to "webm muxer" so that the output is in webm format
the limitation to this method is that you can only start your cut at a keyframe (places that the video can easily seek to), otherwise the video will be glitched

otherwise, you can try these programs that do specialize in encoding:
https://argorar.github.io/WebMConverter/
https://github.com/Kagami/boram

>>1310944
>Almost all pre built ebike companies are shifty chinesium resellers.
Yes, Polarnar in the exposé video at https://youtu.be/saI_kLKWSiE has essentially many of the same looking models as EOHORA. Way too suspicious.

Another characteristic is the max mileage of Eohora bikes is only a substantial fraction of real ebike companies having similar brand motors and battery capacity. Furthermore, Eohora recommends battery usage between no less than 30% remaining capacity and 75% max charged capacity. This is basically less than half of the claimed range in order to avoid early battery failure. So their claim of 1000 charge cycles is done in the usage range of 35% to 75% battery capacity. Charging Eohora over 75% can shorten lifespan and using the battery under 35% remaining capacity can also shorten lifespan.

Recommendation: Ragnarok Online
This is a old Free To Play RPG from beginning to end with 2D sprites navigating in a 3D world environment. You can play solo and ignore other players if you wish or you play with others. It's an open-ended world and you aren't forced down a path or route to get to some ending. But like real life, some people get frozen when there are too many choices! Ragnarok Online is open to the point where you can play a mage who fights with a weapon and eschews magic most of the time. posts.com:
Decode this: ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK

A Twitter snowflake ID is a 64-bit binary number, with 41 bits representing a timestamp, 10 bits representing a machine ID, and 12 bits representing a per-machine sequence number. The snowflake ID is generally serialized in decimal format and is used in the post URL.

For example,
https://twitter.com/i/status/1581674019991916545
Decoding 1581674019991916545:
{'creation_time_milliseconds': 1665935447105,
'datacenter_id': 10,
'machine_id': 337,
'sequence_id': 1,
'server_id': 17}

The filename of a Twitter photo also contains a base64-encoded snowflake ID. This can be decoded into a regular snowflake ID, although it contains three "extra" unknown bytes.
For example,
https://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q?format=jpg
FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q -> 1572620320212922371

It is unknown if the filename of a Twitter video also contains a snowflake ID. You can see the URL contains it, but any off-platform video would would only contain the file name.
For example,
https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1564378065198882816/pu/vid/960x720/ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK.mp4

How would "ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK" be decoded into a snowflake, if it's possible?

Resources:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snowflake_ID
https://discord.com/developers/docs/reference#snowflakes (good visualizations, twitter uses another epoch)
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xVrPoNutyqTdQ04DXBEZW4ZW4A5RAQW2he7qIpTmG-M/edit

>Is this exposure enough to have any negative consequences?
Just be mindful of cross-contamination. For example, you can get lead dust on your clothes and then you sit on furniture in your home. Now that furniture or even flooring has some lead dust. posts.com: So I have Wolf's Rain 720 DVD version, and as far as I know, it's the best version, but unfortunately, I couldn't find English subs for it. they're all timed wrong, and it's a hassle to always change the timing manually every minute. Does anyone know ENG subs for it? or how to time them indefinitely?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1310837
if the subs are otherwise accurate but just progressively creep forward or backward with respect to the audio

Use the visual-sync function in Subtitle Edit to match the first subtitle with the first audio, then the last audio with the last sub, and all the subs inbetween get automatically shifted by a proportional amount.

If however the version you have has different scenes, longer or shorter scenes, uses different transitions because re-edited or anything like that you will probably have to do this multiple times like for instance at the start to the 5 minute mark, then 5 - 10 minutes if it works at all.

Your other option is to manually time all the subs using Subtitle Edit or Aegisub or whatever program you want.

>Wolf's Rain 720 DVD
Perhaps you mean 576p - European PAL DVD.
That would explain why the subtitles go out of sync.
PAL DVD's often speed up 24 FPS to 25 FPS.
If you rip the episodes, you could slow them back down to 24 or 23.976 FPS.

posts.com: I need to know what 2/3rds of 2/3rds of 2/3rds of 2/3rds of 2/3rds of 2/3rds of 2/3rds thank u also if you can explain how to do tge problem for future

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1310629
It's called exponentiation.
https://www.wolframalpha.com/input?i=%282%2F3%29%5E7

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1310629
>2/3rds of 2/3rds of 2/3rds of 2/3rds of 2/3rds of 2/3rds of 2/3rds
Multiply the top by the top and the bottom by the bottom.

2/3rds of 2/3rds of 2/3rds of 2/3rds of 2/3rds of 2/3rds of 2/3rds
= (2/3)*(2/3)*(2/3)*(2/3)*(2/3)*(2/3)*(2/3)
= (2*2*2*2*2*2*2)/(3*3*3*3*3*3*3)
= 128/2187
= 0.05853...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1310629
To do it by hand, multiply all of the numbers on top (the 2s) together and then, separately, multiply all the numbers on the down (the 3s) together. Then divide the big top number from the big bottom number

I wanna make a comedy skit and in the skit I scratch someone’s car. Obviously I don’t want to actually scratch a car, what are some good ways to create the practical effect? I was thinking either a sheet of fake paint to scrape or maybe a sticker and use fake dull keys. But what do you suggest?

The budget is below $200

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1310776
Worst (or best) case you could get a real part of the same model and color and temporarily replace it.
I can't think of any other way of keeping the original one safe.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1310776
Notice that the scratches in that pic are white, that's an undercoat. You have to scratch really hard to get to bare metal. Try experimenting with white powders maybe mixed with water into a thick paste, makeup powder/foundation/eyeshadow which can come in metallic colours, art pastel stick, blackboard chalk, washable or dry erase "chalk" pens/markers, maybe washable paint. Don't use regular paint like house paint, model paint, poster paint, typo correction fluid as these could easily dry or dissolve the topcoat. Do experiment in a safe region as even though chalk is soft but it is a stone and paint is soft too and a fine powder could mar the surface it rubbed on due to it having microscopic points all over the dust fragments.

you want to estimate 190x71
190 = 200-10, 71 =70+1

then a quick estimation would be 190x71 ~= 200x70 = 2x7x100x10 = 14000.
for a better estimation, you substract 70x10 = 700, and you get 13300.
you get the final sum if you add 200-10 = 190: 13300 + 190 = 13490
what did I do here? I used the distributive property of addition and multiplication to make the actual calculation easier:
190x71 = (200-10)x(70+1) = 200x70 - 70x10 + 200 - 10


the actual calculation on paper, step by step:
190x71 = (200 - 10) x (70 + 1) = 200x70 + 200x1 - 10x70 - 10x1
= 2x7x100x10 + 200 - 7x100 - 10
= 14x1000 + 200 - 700 - 10
= 14000 - 500 - 10
= 13500 - 10
= 13400 + (100 - 10)
= 13490
this calculation takes many steps, but a quick estimation is far quicker if you know how to do it and are able to keep the numbers in your mind.

how do you use this in real life? say you are paying a bill: you bought 190 items at 71 cents each, and you want a quick estimation of how much it should cost before paying (so you don't get scammed or whatever), then you do this quick mental calculation and are able to estimate the final cost BEFORE paying anything.

>>1308306
>how do I practice this and develop it?
>What are your ways of long division/multiplication anon? On paper, I need to remind myself of the best ways of those too.
these two are the same question, and have the same answer: learn and memorize the properties of the addition, substraction, multiplication and division, then apply them in convenient ways.


using the same example, >>1307851 . notice that I actually did more things than simply using the distributive property of +/*:

>200x70 = 2x7x100x10 = 14000
here, I applied the associative and commutative properties of multiplication to move the zeros to the end so that I could compute the most difficult calculation (2x7) first and then multiply that for 100x10 (which is easier than 2x7), which is not really a multiplication: it's a matter of adding 3 zeros to the right of 14. ask yourself, why do this? answer: to make both the memorization and calculation in my mind easier to myself.

>190x71 = (200 - 10) x (70 + 1)
again, I came with these numbers, ordered them and applied the properties of the operations (addition, multiplication, substraction) in a way I could make it easy to calculate the final result. I could have used other numbers, say:
190x71 = (150 + 40) x (60 + 11)
and it would be the same result with a different path for calculation, and, most importantly, a different difficulty (for me at least, multiplying anything by 11 becomes more difficult).
THAT is the magic of maths: you can use the numbers and its properties in different ways, you can then find the easier path and enf up with the result you want.

see, that multiplication could be made even more difficult:
190x71 = (127 + 33) x (94 - 23)
but, why do this?

get a basic maths book that teachers the properties of the basic operations (addition, multiplication, substraction, division), do its exercises, then practice the above with random numbers and random "pathways".

>>1307409
Gonna share what I've put together to keep my head straight while learning Maths. Haven't put it to the test for very long, so don't take it as gospel.

You don't necessarily have to start with Arithmetic-I didn't. Start with College Algebra and fill in the gaps in Arithmetic as you go. Actively try and point out what you don't know and figure it out. Make sure to follow along each example provided as well as do the problem sets. Instead of taking notes, I like to write questions, observations, thoughts, etc in the margins of the textbook I'm using. Keep a spare notebook around for your problem sets. You don't need to follow any of the charts shilled on /sci/, just whatever book is readily available to you or provided to you as part of a course. I'd recommend you enroll in a College Algebra course at your local community college.

You won't absorb everything you cover and you'll forget a sizable portion of what you learn after a while, so be mindful of reviewing every so often. Writing notes/comments in the margins comes in handy since you are able to readily see what you were previously stuck on and any insights you made while reading that you might've forgotten since you last covered the section. You are usually provided with insights upon your review of a section, so you'll pick up whatever yo covered more quickly.

PRACTICE PRACTICE PRACTICE! No one can teach you anything; you have to apply you own way of thinking unto what you're learning.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1310795
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polynomial
>In mathematics, a polynomial is an expression consisting of indeterminates (also called variables) and coefficients, that involves only the operations of addition, subtraction, multiplication, and positive-integer powers of variables. An example of a polynomial of a single indeterminate x is x^2 − 4x + 7. An example with three indeterminates is x^3 + 2xyz^2 − yz + 1.

>y = sin(x)
sin is a trigonometric function, so it's not a polynomial.

>y = cos(x)
cos is a trigonometric function, so it's not a polynomial.

>y = 3^x
That's x power of 3, not a positive integer power of x (such as x^3), so it's not a polynomial.

y = x^3
That's a positive integer power of x, so it is a polynomial.

>>1309051
Yeah! ^.^ There are tons of books, movies, series, and manga that explore fusion as a character development device. Some of my faves include Ranma 1/2 (has transformation between humans and animals through special training techniques), Fushigi Yuugi, Kirigaya Suguha (it's about two people sharing a soul through special crystal technology), Revolutionary Girl Utena, Sailor Moon, Attack on Titan, and Mobile Suit Gundam SEED Destiny (though this is more >.< to follow). All of these stories use fusion as an important part of their plotlines and explore its effects on the characters in meaningful ways. If you want to explore something with a little more romance, you could always check out some shoujo manga. There's tons out there that explore fusion and relationships in interesting ways. Hope this helps! <3

>Reconsidering Race: Social Science Perspectives on Racial Categories in the Age of Genomics
>Chapter 10. How Did East Asians Become Yellow?
>ABSTRACT: This chapter offers a brief historical intervention explaining the rise of the term yellow for racial thinking about Asians. Using his binomial nomenclature species-naming system, the Swedish taxonomist Carolus Linnaeus separated Homo sapiens into four continental types, with distinct colors assigned to each. Over two decades later the German anatomist Johann Friedrich Blumenbach also classified Asians as yellow in his five-race scheme. Although some early twentieth-century anthropologists claimed to have proven that Mongolians (Asians) were physically yellow in an attempt to place Asians lower than Europeans, the initial categorization of yellow had no visual or biological basis. As Asians continued to refuse to take part in Western systems (Christianity, international trade), Europeans' perceptions of Asians' skin color darkened. Moreover in the late eighteenth and early nineteenth century, the yellow idea began to spread to East Asian cultures themselves.
